quoteFirst: Wayne’s own duties didn’t begin until eight, and in consequence he had two hours on his hands that he didn’t know what to do with. Breakfast was always over by half-past five and a minute or two later June was streaking across the field to the railroad track. At about
quoteLast: there was a milk train due and June had become an adept at swinging himself to a platform as it slowed down at the yard entrance. Just at first his presence, when discovered, was resented, but presently the train hands good-naturedly failed to see him and he rode into town huddled up on a car step.
title: Second Base Sloan
author: Mathewson, Christy, 1880-1925; Caswell, Edward C., 1879-1963 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: He had thereby shown, he said, that if Miss Frick was the lady who had left the pawnbroker’s at
quoteLast: —which was now an established fact—it could not be she who had been photographed with the diamond in her hand at twenty minutes to six!  That the little clock in the elephant’s head was right to the minute, had been proved by Mr. Frick’s evidence.
title: The Black Tortoise: Being the Strange Story of Old Frick's Diamond
author: Sparre, Christian, 1859-1940; Brækstad, Gertrude Hughes [Translator]

quoteFirst: You then take the main Carlisle road and proceed south on it. As you go you inspect all bridges, railroad tracks, streams, and ground in general for eight hundred yards on either side of the road, but find no enemy. At
quoteLast: you begin your message at the Stiner House. Before you now go south, you investigate for eight hundred yards the roads leading to the east and west from the main cross-roads south of Stiner.
title: The English of military communications
author: Ganoe, William Addleman, 1881-1966

quoteFirst: Each division has its own crew, so that the men leaving New York are relieved at Syracuse by others, and these in turn at Cleveland. The New York crew go to work, as has been said, at 4 P.M., and if the train is on time at Syracuse, as it usually is, they arrive there at
quoteLast: , after thirteen and a half hours of as hard work as men are called upon to do. The same evening at 8.

quoteFirst: Quickly, the emergency Earth-originated command was prepared for transmission. At
quoteLast: , PST, a radio signal went out from Goldstone’s Echo Station. Thirty-six million miles away, Mariner II responded to the tiny pulse of energy from the Earth and began its encounter sequence.
title: Mariner Mission to Venus
author: Jet Propulsion Laboratory (U.S.)

quoteFirst: “Four hours and six minutes,” he said. “I looked at my watch when you hooked him, and it was then just a minute or two before half-past one; and I looked at my watch when Sandy gaffed him--it was then
quoteLast: . I counted the number of times the fish jumped, and it was seventeen. I don’t suppose you noticed it,” he added, “but there was a cart going off with peats, near the loch, soon after you began to play the fish, and it came back again not long ago.
title: Amid the High Hills

quoteFirst: In the meantime, I asked the lawyer if he had taken note of the fact that the pawnbroker’s time by the clock had made it impossible that Miss Frick could be back at Villa Ballarat at the time when the photograph was taken.  According to the pawnbroker’s account, she drove from there
quoteLast: , and the clock in the photograph showed it to be twenty minutes to six.  The way from Bishop Road to Villa Ballarat cannot be covered in five minutes.
title: The Black Tortoise: Being the Strange Story of Old Frick's Diamond
author: Sparre, Christian, 1859-1940; Brækstad, Gertrude Hughes [Translator]
